title: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
chunks.html_content:
Employees may be eligible for Statutory Paternity Leave and Pay if they and their partner are:

  • having a baby
  • adopting a child
  • having a baby through a surrogacy arrangement
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Employees may be eligible for Statutory Paternity Leave and Pay if they and their partner are:

  having a baby
  adopting a child
  having a baby through a surrogacy arrangement

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
chunks.html_content: This guide is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg).
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
This guide is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg).

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Statutory Paternity Leave
chunks.html_content:
Employees can choose to take either 1 week or 2 consecutive weeks’ leave. The amount of time is the same even if they have more than one child (for example twins).

Leave cannot start before the birth. The start date must be one of the following:

  • the actual date of birth
  • an agreed number of days after the birth
  • an agreed number of days after the expected week of childbirth

Leave must finish within 56 days of the birth (or due date if the baby is early). The start and end dates are different if the employee is adopting.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Statutory Paternity Leave
Employees can choose to take either 1 week or 2 consecutive weeks’ leave. The amount of time is the same even if they have more than one child (for example twins).
Leave cannot start before the birth. The start date must be one of the following:

  the actual date of birth
  an agreed number of days after the birth
  an agreed number of days after the expected week of childbirth

Leave must finish within 56 days of the birth (or due date if the baby is early). The start and end dates are different if the employee is adopting.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Statutory Paternity Pay
chunks.html_content: Statutory Paternity Pay for eligible employees is either £172.48 a week or 90% of their average weekly earnings (whichever is lower). Tax and National Insurance need to be deducted.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Statutory Paternity Pay
Statutory Paternity Pay for eligible employees is either £172.48 a week or 90% of their average weekly earnings (whichever is lower). Tax and National Insurance need to be deducted.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Statutory Paternity Pay
chunks.html_content: Calculate an employee’s paternity leave and pay using the maternity and paternity calculator.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Statutory Paternity Pay
Calculate an employee’s paternity leave and pay using the maternity and paternity calculator.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Statutory Paternity Pay
chunks.html_content: Some employment types, like agency workers, directors and educational workers, have different rules for entitlement.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Statutory Paternity Pay
Some employment types, like agency workers, directors and educational workers, have different rules for entitlement.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Extra leave or pay
chunks.html_content:
Employees can get more leave or pay if:

  • their partner returns to work and they qualify for Shared Parental Leave and Pay
  • your company scheme offers more

You must make sure your paternity leave and pay policies are clear and easily accessible to staff.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Extra leave or pay
Employees can get more leave or pay if:

  their partner returns to work and they qualify for Shared Parental Leave and Pay

  your company scheme offers more

You must make sure your paternity leave and pay policies are clear and easily accessible to staff.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Leave for antenatal appointments
chunks.html_content:
Employees can take unpaid leave to accompany a pregnant woman to antenatal appointments if they are:

  • the baby’s father
  • the expectant mother’s spouse or civil partner
  • in a long term relationship with the expectant mother
  • the intended parent (if they’re having a baby through a surrogacy arrangement)

They can accompany the woman to 2 appointments of up to 6 and a half hours each.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Leave for antenatal appointments
Employees can take unpaid leave to accompany a pregnant woman to antenatal appointments if they are:

  the baby’s father
  the expectant mother’s spouse or civil partner
  in a long term relationship with the expectant mother
  the intended parent (if they’re having a baby through a surrogacy arrangement)

They can accompany the woman to 2 appointments of up to 6 and a half hours each.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
If the baby dies
chunks.html_content:
Employees still qualify for paternity leave and pay if the baby is either:

  • stillborn from 24 weeks of pregnancy
  • born alive at any point in the pregnancy but later dies
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
If the baby dies
Employees still qualify for paternity leave and pay if the baby is either:

  stillborn from 24 weeks of pregnancy
  born alive at any point in the pregnancy but later dies

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Employment rights
chunks.html_content: An employee’s employment rights (like the right to pay, holidays and returning to a job) are protected during paternity leave. You still have to pay Statutory Paternity Pay even if you stop trading.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Employment rights
An employee’s employment rights (like the right to pay, holidays and returning to a job) are protected during paternity leave. You still have to pay Statutory Paternity Pay even if you stop trading.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
chunks.html_content:
Employees must be one of the following, the:

  • father
  • husband or partner of the mother (or adopter)
  • child’s adopter
  • intended parent (if they’re having a baby through a surrogacy arrangement)

Employees must also:

  • be classed as an employee (paternity leave only)
  • be employed by you up to the date the child is born (or placed with the adopter) (paternity pay only)
  • be on your payroll and earn at least £123 a week (gross) in an 8 week ‘relevant period’ (paternity pay only)
  • give you the correct notice
  • be taking time off to look after the child or their partner
  • be responsible for the child’s upbringing
  • have been continuously employed by you for at least 26 weeks up to any day in the ‘qualifying week’

If your employee usually earns an average of £123 or more a week, and they only earned less in some weeks because they were paid but not working (‘on furlough’) under the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme, they may still be eligible.

The qualifying week is the 15th week before the baby is due. This is different if the employee is adopting.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Employees must be one of the following, the:

  father
  husband or partner of the mother (or adopter)
  child’s adopter
  intended parent (if they’re having a baby through a surrogacy arrangement)

Employees must also:

  be classed as an employee (paternity leave only)
  be employed by you up to the date the child is born (or placed with the adopter) (paternity pay only)
  be on your payroll and earn at least £123 a week (gross) in an 8 week ‘relevant period’ (paternity pay only)
  give you the correct notice

  be taking time off to look after the child or their partner
  be responsible for the child’s upbringing
  have been continuously employed by you for at least 26 weeks up to any day in the ‘qualifying week’

If your employee usually earns an average of £123 or more a week, and they only earned less in some weeks because they were paid but not working (‘on furlough’) under the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme, they may still be eligible.
The qualifying week is the 15th week before the baby is due. This is different if the employee is adopting.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
chunks.html_content: Use the paternity pay calculator to check an employee’s eligibility and work out their relevant period, notice period and paternity pay.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Use the paternity pay calculator to check an employee’s eligibility and work out their relevant period, notice period and paternity pay.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
If the child is born early
chunks.html_content:
There are special rules for some employee situations, for example if they leave or become sick.

If the child is born early, the employee is still eligible if they would have worked for you continuously for at least 26 weeks by the qualifying week.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
If the child is born early
There are special rules for some employee situations, for example if they leave or become sick.
If the child is born early, the employee is still eligible if they would have worked for you continuously for at least 26 weeks by the qualifying week.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
If the child is born early
chunks.html_content: For very premature births where the child is born 15 weeks before the due date, you’ll need to calculate paternity pay using your payroll software (if it has this feature) or work it out manually.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
If the child is born early
For very premature births where the child is born 15 weeks before the due date, you’ll need to calculate paternity pay using your payroll software (if it has this feature) or work it out manually.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Employees in surrogacy arrangements
chunks.html_content:
Parents intending to have a child through a surrogacy arrangement may be eligible for Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave.

If you ask, they must give you a written statement to confirm that they’ve applied or intend to apply for a parental order in the 6 months after the baby’s birth.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Employees in surrogacy arrangements
Parents intending to have a child through a surrogacy arrangement may be eligible for Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave.
If you ask, they must give you a written statement to confirm that they’ve applied or intend to apply for a parental order in the 6 months after the baby’s birth.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
chunks.html_content: The notice periods and forms are different if the employee is adopting.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
The notice periods and forms are different if the employee is adopting.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Statutory Paternity Leave
chunks.html_content:
Employees must tell you at least 15 weeks before the week the baby is expected:

  • the baby’s due date
  • when they want their leave to start - they can change this with 28 days’ notice
  • how much leave they want

Notice does not have to be in writing unless you request it.

Employees can ask for leave and pay in writing using the online form. This replaces form SC3. Employees will need to download or print the form after completing it and give you a copy.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Statutory Paternity Leave
Employees must tell you at least 15 weeks before the week the baby is expected:

  the baby’s due date
  when they want their leave to start  - they can change this with 28 days’ notice
  how much leave they want

Notice does not have to be in writing unless you request it.
Employees can ask for leave and pay in writing using the online form. This replaces form SC3. Employees will need to download or print the form after completing it and give you a copy.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Statutory Paternity Pay
chunks.html_content:
Employees must request paternity pay at least 15 weeks before the week the baby is expected.

Notice does not have to be in writing unless you request it.

Employees can ask for leave and pay in writing using the online form. Employees will need to download or print the form after completing it and give you a copy.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Statutory Paternity Pay
Employees must request paternity pay at least 15 weeks before the week the baby is expected.
Notice does not have to be in writing unless you request it.
Employees can ask for leave and pay in writing using the online form. Employees will need to download or print the form after completing it and give you a copy.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Statutory Paternity Pay
chunks.html_content: Employees having a baby through a surrogacy arrangement must use form SC4 to request leave and pay.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Statutory Paternity Pay
Employees having a baby through a surrogacy arrangement must use form SC4 to request leave and pay.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Late notice
chunks.html_content: You can delay the leave or pay start date if the employee does not have a reasonable excuse for giving you the wrong amount of notice. To delay it, write to them within 28 days of their leave request.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Late notice
You can delay the leave or pay start date if the employee does not have a reasonable excuse for giving you the wrong amount of notice. To delay it, write to them within 28 days of their leave request.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
chunks.html_content: Eligible employees are entitled to paternity leave and pay if they’re adopting a child.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Eligible employees are entitled to paternity leave and pay if they’re adopting a child.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
chunks.html_content: Calculate an employee’s paternity leave and pay using the maternity and paternity calculator. For overseas adoptions you’ll need to use your payroll software (if it has this feature) or work it out manually.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Calculate an employee’s paternity leave and pay using the maternity and paternity calculator. For overseas adoptions you’ll need to use your payroll software (if it has this feature) or work it out manually.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Eligibility
chunks.html_content:
An employee adopting a child must:

  • have been continuously employed by you for at least 26 weeks up to any day in the week they were matched with a child (UK adoptions)
  • have been continuously employed by you for at least 26 weeks by either the date the child arrives in the UK or when they want their pay to start (overseas adoptions)
  • confirm that their partner is getting Statutory Adoption Pay in writing or by giving you a copy of their partner’s form SC6
  • meet the other eligibility conditions for paternity leave or pay
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Eligibility
An employee adopting a child must:

  have been continuously employed by you for at least 26 weeks up to any day in the week they were matched with a child (UK adoptions)
  have been continuously employed by you for at least 26 weeks by either the date the child arrives in the UK or when they want their pay to start (overseas adoptions)
  confirm that their partner is getting Statutory Adoption Pay in writing or by giving you a copy of their partner’s form SC6

  meet the other eligibility conditions for paternity leave or pay

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Notice period
chunks.html_content:
An employee adopting a child must send you form SC4 for:

  • leave - no later than 7 days of their co-adopter or partner being matched with a child
  • pay - 28 days before they want their pay to start

For overseas adoptions the form and notice period is different. The process is explained on form SC5.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Notice period
An employee adopting a child must send you form SC4 for:

  leave - no later than 7 days of their co-adopter or partner being matched with a child
  pay - 28 days before they want their pay to start

For overseas adoptions the form and notice period is different. The process is explained on form SC5.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Leave start date
chunks.html_content:
An employee taking paternity leave because they’re adopting can start their leave:

  • on the date of placement
  • an agreed number of days after the date of placement
  • on the date the child arrives in the UK or an agreed number of days after this (overseas adoptions)

For overseas adoptions leave must be taken within 56 days of the date of placement or the child’s arrival in the UK.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Leave start date
An employee taking paternity leave because they’re adopting can start their leave:

  on the date of placement
  an agreed number of days after the date of placement
  on the date the child arrives in the UK or an agreed number of days after this (overseas adoptions)

For overseas adoptions leave must be taken within 56 days of the date of placement or the child’s arrival in the UK.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Proof of adoption
chunks.html_content:
Employees must give you proof of adoption to qualify for paternity pay. Proof is not needed for paternity leave unless you request it. Proof can be a letter from their adoption agency or their matching certificate.

You must keep records of the proof.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
Proof of adoption
Employees must give you proof of adoption to qualify for paternity pay. Proof is not needed for paternity leave unless you request it. Proof can be a letter from their adoption agency or their matching certificate.
You must keep records of the proof.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
chunks.html_content:
You can refuse Statutory Paternity Pay if the employee does not qualify. To do this send them form SPP1 within 28 days of their pay request. You must keep a copy.

The employee can ask you for a written statement explaining your decision. You have to give this to them within a reasonable time, for example 7 working days.
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
You can refuse Statutory Paternity Pay if the employee does not qualify. To do this send them form SPP1 within 28 days of their pay request. You must keep a copy.
The employee can ask you for a written statement explaining your decision. You have to give this to them within a reasonable time, for example 7 working days.

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
chunks.html_content:
You must keep records for HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC), including:

  • the date Statutory Paternity Pay started
  • the paternity payments you’ve made (including dates)
  • the payments you’ve reclaimed
  • any weeks you did not pay and why
  • if adopting, a letter from the adoption agency or a matching certificate

You must keep records for 3 years from the end of the tax year they relate to (for example by using form SPP2 or keeping your own records).
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
You must keep records for HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC), including:

  the date Statutory Paternity Pay started
  the paternity payments you’ve made (including dates)
  the payments you’ve reclaimed

  any weeks you did not pay and why
  if adopting, a letter from the adoption agency or a matching certificate

You must keep records for 3 years from the end of the tax year they relate to (for example by using form SPP2 or keeping your own records).

heading_context: Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
chunks.html_content:
For financial help with statutory pay, you can:

  • reclaim payments (usually 92%)
  • apply for an advance if you cannot afford payments
chunks.plain_content:
Statutory Paternity Pay and Leave: employer guide
For financial help with statutory pay, you can:

  reclaim payments (usually 92%)
  apply for an advance if you cannot afford payments
